title: What is a Neural Network?
description:
📌 A computational model inspired by the human brain.
✅ Composed of layers of neurons that process information.
🔍 Example: Used in speech recognition and self-driving cars.
👉 Have you ever interacted with an AI-powered system?

title: Artificial Neuron: The Building Block
description:
📌 A mathematical model mimicking biological neurons.
✅ Takes inputs, applies weights, sums them, applies activation function.
🔍 Example: Predicting house prices based on size, location, and features.
👉 Can you think of an everyday task a neuron model could automate?

title: Types of Neural Networks
description:
📌 Various architectures designed for different tasks.
✅ Feedforward (FNN), Convolutional (CNN), Recurrent (RNN), Generative Adversarial (GANs), Transformer.
🔍 Example: CNNs for image processing, RNNs for speech recognition.
👉 Which type of neural network interests you the most?

title: Activation Functions
description:
📌 Determines whether a neuron should be activated.
✅ Common types: Sigmoid, ReLU, Tanh, Softmax.
🔍 Example: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) is widely used in deep learning.
👉 Which activation function do you think is best for complex problems?

title: Feedforward Neural Networks (FNN)
description:
📌 The simplest type of neural network.
✅ Data moves in one direction, no loops.
🔍 Example: Basic classification tasks like spam detection.
👉 Where have you encountered simple classification problems?

title: Backpropagation & Gradient Descent
description:
📌 The learning mechanism of neural networks.
✅ Backpropagation adjusts weights to minimize error.
🔍 Example: Training an AI to recognize handwritten digits.
👉 Have you ever seen an AI improve over time with training?

title: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)
description:
📌 Specialized for image recognition and processing.
✅ Uses convolution layers to detect edges, textures, and patterns.
🔍 Example: Face recognition in smartphones.
👉 Can you think of another application of CNNs?

title: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)
description:
📌 Designed for sequential data like speech and text.
✅ Has memory, allowing previous inputs to influence future predictions.
🔍 Example: Predicting the next word in a sentence (e.g., autocomplete).
👉 Have you noticed predictive text improving over time?

title: Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)
description:
📌 A special type of RNN that overcomes short-term memory limitations.
✅ Maintains long-term dependencies.
🔍 Example: Machine translation and speech recognition.
👉 Have you used a language translation tool recently?

title: Transformer Networks & Attention Mechanism
description:
📌 The backbone of modern NLP models like GPT.
✅ Uses self-attention to process entire sequences in parallel.
🔍 Example: ChatGPT, Google Translate, BERT.
👉 How do you see transformers shaping the future of AI?

title: Overfitting in Neural Networks
description:
📌 When a model memorizes training data instead of generalizing.
✅ Solutions: Regularization, Dropout, Data Augmentation.
🔍 Example: A neural network that performs well on training data but fails on new data.
👉 Have you encountered AI making overly confident but incorrect predictions?

title: Dropout: Preventing Overfitting
description:
📌 A regularization technique in deep learning.
✅ Randomly ignores neurons during training to improve generalization.
🔍 Example: Helps CNNs perform better on unseen images.
👉 Can you think of an analogy for why removing some neurons helps?

title: Loss Functions in Neural Networks
description:
📌 Measures how well a model's predictions match actual values.
✅ Common types: Mean Squared Error (MSE), Cross-Entropy Loss.
🔍 Example: Cross-entropy loss is used in classification tasks.
👉 Have you ever heard of loss functions in optimization problems?

title: Optimizers in Neural Networks
description:
📌 Algorithms to update weights and minimize loss.
✅ Popular ones: Gradient Descent, Adam, RMSprop.
🔍 Example: Adam optimizer helps deep networks converge faster.
👉 Do you think a good optimizer is more important than a complex model?

title: Autoencoders: Learning Efficient Representations
description:
📌 Neural networks for unsupervised learning.
✅ Encode input data into a compressed representation, then reconstruct it.
🔍 Example: Denoising images, anomaly detection in security.
👉 Where do you think data compression is most useful?

title: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
description:
📌 Neural networks that create new, realistic data.
✅ Composed of a generator and a discriminator competing against each other.
🔍 Example: Deepfake videos, AI-generated artwork.
👉 What are the ethical implications of AI-generated content?

title: Neural Style Transfer
description:
📌 Using deep learning to apply artistic styles to images.
✅ Extracts features from one image and applies them to another.
🔍 Example: Turning a photo into a Van Gogh-style painting.
👉 Have you ever used AI-based photo filters?

title: Neural Networks in Healthcare
description:
📌 AI-driven medical diagnosis and analysis.
✅ Detecting diseases from medical images, predicting patient outcomes.
🔍 Example: AI-assisted cancer detection in radiology.
👉 Do you think AI should have more control in medical decisions?

title: Self-Supervised Learning in Neural Networks
description:
📌 Learning without labeled data by generating pseudo-labels.
✅ Helps train large AI models with minimal human supervision.
🔍 Example: Facebook’s AI for facial recognition without manual labeling.
👉 How could self-supervised learning change AI development?

title: Ethical Concerns in Neural Networks
description:
📌 Bias, privacy issues, and AI decision accountability.
✅ AI models can inherit biases from training data.
🔍 Example: Facial recognition bias affecting certain demographics.
👉 How should we address fairness in AI systems?
